details.title: Goodness-of-fit tests based on spacings for progressively type-II censored data from a general location-scale distribution
details.standardTitle: Goodness-of-fit tests based on spacings for progressively type-II censored data from a general location-scale distribution

p: N. Balakrishnan is Professor of Statistics in the Department of Mathematics and Statistics at McMaster University. He received his Ph. D. in 1981 from the Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur, India. He has been at McMaster University since 1985. His research interests include order statistics, statistical inference and distribution theory. He is a Fellow of the American Statistical Association and currently the Editor-in Chief of Communications in Statistics and the Encyclopedia of Statistical Sciences.

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Math. & Stat., McMaster Univ., Hamilton, Ont., Canada
authors.name: N. Balakrishnan

p: H. K. T. Ng is Assistant Professor in the Department of Statistical Science at Southern Methodist University. He received his Ph. D. in 2002 from McMaster University, Hamilton, Canada. He has been at Southern Methodist University since August 2002. His research interests include reliability, nonparametric methods and statistical inference. He is a member of the American Statistical Association.

N. Kannan is Associate Professor in the Department of Management Science and Statistics at University of Texas, San Antonio. She received her Ph. D. in 1993 from Pennsylvania State University at State College, Pennsylvania. She has been at the University of Texas, San Antonio, since 1993. Her research interests include signal processing and statistical inference. She is a member of the American Statistical Association and the Institute of Mathematical Statistics, and is currently an Associate Editor of Communications in Statistics.

details.abstract: There has been extensive research on goodness-of-fit procedures for testing whether or not a sample comes from a specified distribution. These goodness-of-fit tests range from graphical techniques, to tests which exploit characterization results for the specified underlying model. In this article, we propose a goodness-of-fit test for the location-scale family based on progressively Type-II censored data. The test statistic is based on sample spacings, and generalizes a test procedure proposed by Tiku . The null distribution of the test statistic is shown to be approximated closely by a s-normal distribution. However, in certain situations it would be better to use simulated critical values instead of the s-normal approximation. We examine the performance of this test for the s-normal and extreme-value (Gumbel) models against different alternatives through Monte Carlo simulations. We also discuss two methods of power approximation based on s-normality, and compare the results with those obtained by simulation. Results of the simulation study for a wide range of sample sizes, censoring schemes, and different alternatives reveal that the proposed test has good power properties in detecting departures from the s-normal and Gumbel distributions. Finally, we illustrate the method proposed here using real data from a life-testing experiment. It is important to mention here that this test can be extended to multi-sample situations in a manner similar to that of Balakrishnan et al.

context.text: The statistic \$T\$ was suggested by Tiku [1] for complete, and doubly Type-II censored samples.

references.title: Goodness of fit statistics based on the spacings of complete or censored samples
references.text: M. L. Tiku, "Goodness of fit statistics based on the spacings of complete or censored samples", Australian Journal of Statistics, vol. 22, pp. 260-275, 1980.

context.text: [2] have constructed a similar test for the exponential distribution under progressive Type-II censoring.
[2] have shown that for testing exponentiality, the null distribution of the test statistic \$T\$ is exactly the same as the average of \$m-2\$ i.i.d.

references.title: A test of exponentiality based on spacings for progressively type-ii censored data
references.text: C. Huber-Carol, N. Balakrishnan, M. S. Nikulin, M. Mesbah, "A test of exponentiality based on spacings for progressively type-ii censored data" in Goodness-of-Fit Tests and Model Validity, pp. 89-110, 2001, Birkhäuser.

context.text: The properties of this and other “omnibus” tests have been investigated extensively; see, for example, D'Agostino and Stephens [3].
D'Agostino and Stephens [3] provide an extensive review of tests for other distributions including the \$s\$-uniform, Weibull, and Gumbel.

references.title: Goodness-of-Fit Techniques
references.text: R. B. D'Agostino, M. A. Stephens, Goodness-of-Fit Techniques, 1986, Marcel Dekker.

context.text: For example, for the exponential distribution, one can exploit the fact that the hazard function is constant, or that the logarithm of the survival function is linear; see Shapiro [4], and Stephens [5].

references.text: N. Balakrishnan, A. P. Basu, "Goodness-of-fit tests" in The Exponential Distribution: Theory Methods and Applications, 1995, Gordon and Breach.

context.text: Shapiro and Wilk [6] developed a test statistic based on the ratio of the best linear unbiased estimate (BLUE) of \$\sigma^{2}\$ to the sample variance.

references.text: S. S. Shapiro, M. B. Wilk, "An analysis of variance test for normality", Biometrika, vol. 52, pp. 591-611, 1965.

links.abstract: Presents nearly coincident observations of backscattering from the ERS-1 SAR and of near-surface temperature from drifting buoys in the Beaufort Sea during 1991 and 1992, showing that the onset of melt and fall freeze-up can be detected precisely in the SAR data. Melt onset is marked by a clean steep decrease in backscattering from multiyear ice at 5.3 GHz. The authors show that this decrease is due solely to the appearance of liquid water in snow covering the multiyear ice. Freeze-up is marked ...

context.text: For these and other reasons, progressive censoring has been discussed by Nelson [7].
In reliability and life-testing applications, the log-normal and Weibull distributions are extensively used to model lifetime of items (see Nelson [7] for examples).
We consider the following data of times to breakdown of an insulating fluid tested at 34 kilovolts taken from Table 6.1 of Nelson [7], and considered by Viveros and Balakrishnan [15].

The observations in the log time scale, the progressive censoring pattern, and the sample spacings \$G_{i}\$ are as follows:

Nelson [7], and Viveros and Balakrishnan [15], considered a Weibull model in the original time scale so that the log-times to breakdown can be treated as Gumbel observations.
Incidentally, this is consistent with the informal findings of Nelson [7], and Viveros & Balakrishnan [15].

references.title: Applied Life Data Analysis
references.text: W. Nelson, Applied Life Data Analysis, 1982.

context.text: The idea of progressive censoring is due to Cohen [8], [9].

references.title: Progressively censored samples in life testing
references.text: A. C. Cohen, "Progressively censored samples in life testing", Technometrics, vol. 5, pp. 327-329, 1963.

context.text: The idea of progressive censoring is due to Cohen [8], [9].

references.title: Life testing and early failure
references.text: A. C. Cohen, "Life testing and early failure", Technometrics, vol. 8, pp. 539-549, 1966.

context.text: For an elaborate discussion on properties and applications of progressive censoring, the reader may refer to the recent book by Balakrishnan and Aggarwala [10].

If the underlying distribution is exponential, \$S_{1},S_{2},\ldots,S_{m}\$ are independent and identically distributed as exponential with scale parameter \$\sigma\$; see Balakrishnan and Aggarwala [10] for details.
This observation is consistent with the findings of Balakrishnan and Aggarwala [10] p. 191 on optimal censoring schemes for the Gumbel distribution.

references.title: Progressive Censoring: Theory, Methods, and Applications
references.text: N. Balakrishnan, R. Aggarwala, Progressive Censoring: Theory Methods and Applications, 2000, Birkhäuser.
